Notes: Oakwood College, now University, (opened 1896) established its archives in 1973 to preserve source materials related to African-American Seventh-day Adventists. Oakwood College, the Seventh-day Adventist Church, and Adventism among African-Americans are among the topics documented.  Organizational records, private manuscripts, correspondence, publications, minutes, still pictures, sound recordings, slides, motion pictures, and oral histories are found among the holdings, which date from 1896.  Individual collections include papers of Eva B. Dykes, the first African-American woman to complete a Ph.D. degree in the United States; the papers of the late Dr. Otis B. Edwards, an Oakwood faculty member and administrator who conducted research on the history of the college; and a collection of records containing biographical information regarding prominent African-American SDA womeN  The Museum Exhibit Room houses displays of historic documents, artifacts, and memorabilia of the college and the denomination.
Source of Repository Data: Alabama Department of Archives and History
